7613.bart_summary: Jennifer Pagonis, 29, has Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), a very rare disorder affecting 1 in 20,000 which prevents a womb from growing and causes testes to grow in the abdomen. She was born with an enlarged clitoris, no uterus and a partial vagina that surgeons later extended so that as an adult she might have normal sexual intercourse. Undescended testes were also removed from her abdomen to prevent them from developing cancer; although some doctors now think affected children can be monitored instead. She now uses the first name 'Pidgeon,' doesn't identify as female or male and works as an intersex activist against surgery.

7767.highlights:
Jean Sharon Abbott, 38, from Plymouth, Minnesota, was told she had spastic diplegia, a form of cerebral palsy, when she was four-years-old .
She was 33-years-old when she learned she actually had dopa-responsive dystonia (DRD), a rare muscle disorder that can be treated with one pill .
Jean, who was nearly immobile for 30 years, went on a 10-mile hike four months after she was given her new medication, which is known as L-Dopa .
Despite her misdiagnosis, the mother-of-three insists she feels no resentment or anger about her doctor’s life-altering mistake .

After three decades of suffering from muscle spasms, weakness, near immobility, as well as undergoing painful surgical procedures, she learned at the age of 33 that she actually had dopa-responsive dystonia (DRD), a rare, yet treatable, muscle disorder. Her neurologist told her she had actually been living with DRD and that most of her symptoms would improve or disappear with a daily dose of L-Dopa.
